hints_html: A good start would be to find the eigenvalues and eigenvectors. This way you can see how the solution trajectories behave (growing/shrinking) in different directions.
hints_latex:
A good start would be to find the eigenvalues and eigenvectors. This way
you can see how the solution trajectories behave (growing/shrinking) in
different directions.
hints_raw: A good start would be to find the eigenvalues and eigenvectors. This way you can see how the solution trajectories behave (growing/shrinking) in different directions.
question: 5 (a)
sols_html:
We begin by finding the eigenvalues and eigenvectors.

The characteristic polynomial of \(\begin{bmatrix} 0 & 3 \\ 2 & 1 \end{bmatrix}\) is \(\lambda^2 - \lambda - 6 = (\lambda - 3)(\lambda + 2)\) which has roots \(\lambda = 3, -2\). The find the eigenvector with eigenvalue \(\lambda\), we seek the nullspace of \(A - \lambda I\).

With \(\lambda = 3\), we have:

\[\begin{aligned} \begin{bmatrix}-3 & 3 \\ 2 & -2 \end{bmatrix} \vec{v} = \vec{0}.\end{aligned}\]

From the equation implied by the first row (the second is redundant), \(-3 v_1 + 3v_2 = 0\) so we can take \(\vec{v} = \langle 1,1\rangle\).

With \(\lambda = -2\), we have:

\[\begin{aligned} \begin{bmatrix}2 & 3 \\ 2 & 3 \end{bmatrix} \vec{v} = \vec{0}.\end{aligned}\]

From the equation implied by the first row (the second is the same), \(2 v_1 + 3 v_2 = 0\) so we can take \(\vec{v} = \langle 3,-2 \rangle\) as an eigenvector.

The general solution is \(\vec{x}(t) = C_1 \begin{bmatrix}1 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix} e^{3t} + C_2 \begin{bmatrix}3 \\ -2 \end{bmatrix} e^{-2t}\).

The origin is a saddle point because the eigenvalues are real and of opposite sign. Along the \(\displaystyle \langle 1,1\rangle\) direction, the solution grows exponentially. Along the \(\displaystyle \langle 3,-2\rangle\) direction, the solution decays exponentially. At all other points, it will approach the line spanned by \(\displaystyle \langle 1,1\rangle\) as \(t \rightarrow \infty\). This is displayed in the figure.
sols_latex:
We begin by finding the eigenvalues and eigenvectors.

The characteristic polynomial of
$\begin{bmatrix} 0 & 3 \\ 2 & 1 \end{bmatrix}$ is
$\lambda^2 - \lambda - 6 = (\lambda - 3)(\lambda + 2)$ which has roots
$\lambda = 3, -2$. The find the eigenvector with eigenvalue $\lambda$,
we seek the nullspace of $A - \lambda I$.

With $\lambda = 3$, we have:

\begin{align*}
\begin{bmatrix}-3 & 3 \\ 2 & -2 \end{bmatrix} \vec{v} = \vec{0}.
\end{align*}

From the equation implied by the first row (the second is redundant),
$-3 v_1 + 3v_2 = 0$ so we can take $\vec{v} = \langle 1,1\rangle$.

With $\lambda = -2$, we have:

\begin{align*}
\begin{bmatrix}2 & 3 \\ 2 & 3 \end{bmatrix} \vec{v} = \vec{0}.
\end{align*}

From the equation implied by the first row (the second is the same),
$2 v_1 + 3 v_2 = 0$ so we can take $\vec{v} = \langle 3,-2 \rangle$ as
an eigenvector.

The general solution is
$\vec{x}(t) = C_1 \begin{bmatrix}1 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix} e^{3t} + C_2 \begin{bmatrix}3 \\ -2 \end{bmatrix} e^{-2t}$.

The origin is a saddle point because the eigenvalues are real and of
opposite sign. Along the $\displaystyle \langle 1,1\rangle$ direction,
the solution grows exponentially. Along the
$\displaystyle \langle 3,-2\rangle$ direction, the solution decays
exponentially. At all other points, it will approach the line spanned by
$\displaystyle \langle 1,1\rangle$ as $t \rightarrow \infty$. This is
displayed in the figure.

\includegraphics[width=0.5\textwidth]{../json_data/MATH215/December_2013/Wiki5asketch_2013WT1.png}
sols_raw:
We begin by finding the eigenvalues and eigenvectors.

The characteristic polynomial of <math>\begin{bmatrix} 0 & 3 \\ 2 & 1 \end{bmatrix}</math> is <math> \lambda^2 - \lambda - 6 = (\lambda - 3)(\lambda + 2)</math> which has roots <math>\lambda = 3, -2</math>. The find the eigenvector with eigenvalue <math>\lambda</math>, we seek the nullspace of <math>A - \lambda I</math>.

With <math>\lambda = 3</math>, we have:

:<math>\begin{bmatrix}-3 & 3 \\ 2 & -2 \end{bmatrix} \vec{v} = \vec{0}.</math>

From the equation implied by the first row (the second is redundant), <math>-3 v_1 + 3v_2 = 0</math> so we can take <math>\vec{v} = \langle 1,1\rangle </math>.

With <math>\lambda = -2</math>, we have:

:<math>\begin{bmatrix}2 & 3 \\ 2 & 3 \end{bmatrix} \vec{v} = \vec{0}</math>.

From the equation implied by the first row (the second is the same), <math>2 v_1 + 3 v_2 = 0</math> so we can take <math>\vec{v} = \langle 3,-2 \rangle</math> as an eigenvector.

The general solution is <math>\vec{x}(t) = C_1 \begin{bmatrix}1 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix} e^{3t} + C_2 \begin{bmatrix}3 \\ -2 \end{bmatrix} e^{-2t}</math>.

The origin is a saddle point because the eigenvalues are real and of opposite sign. Along the <math>\displaystyle \langle 1,1\rangle</math> direction, the solution grows exponentially. Along the <math>\displaystyle \langle 3,-2\rangle</math> direction, the solution decays exponentially. At all other points, it will approach the line spanned by <math>\displaystyle \langle 1,1\rangle </math> as <math>t \rightarrow \infty</math>. This is displayed in the figure.

[[File:Wiki5asketch 2013WT1.png|300px|Saddle point phase portrait]]
statement_html:
Find the general solution \(\vec{x}(t) = \left[ \begin{array}{c} x(t) \\ y(t) \end{array} \right]\) of the homogeneous linear system

\[\begin{aligned} \vec{x}' = A \vec{x}, \qquad A = \left[ \begin{array}{cc} 0 & 3 \\ 2 & 1 \end{array} \right],\end{aligned}\]

and sketch the phase portrait (i.e. some typical trajectories in the \(xy-\) plane).
statement_raw:
Find the general solution <math>\vec{x}(t) = \left[ \begin{array}{c}
x(t) \\ y(t) \end{array} \right]</math> of the homogeneous linear system

:<math>
\vec{x}' = A \vec{x}, \qquad A = \left[ \begin{array}{cc} 0 & 3 \\ 2 & 1 \end{array} \right],
</math>

and sketch the phase portrait (i.e. some typical trajectories in the <math>xy-</math> plane).
